questions.text: What is the primary function of surfactant in the lungs? (NEET 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduction in surface tension

 

Explanation:


Surfactant plays a critical role in the lungs by reducing the surface tension at the air-liquid interface within the alveoli. This reduction in surface tension is vital to prevent the collapse of the alveoli, particularly during the exhalation phase of breathing. Surfactant achieves this by disrupting the cohesive forces between water molecules lining the alveoli, which are primarily responsible for the high surface tension. The most important component of surfactant, dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPCC), helps stabilize the alveoli and keeps them open throughout the breathing cycle, facilitating gas exchange and maintaining proper lung function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increases O2 diffusion: Incorrect, as surfactant does not directly affect oxygen diffusion; it primarily influences mechanical properties of the lungs.

 

Option B. Decreases airway resistance: Incorrect, surfactant's main function is related to the alveoli rather than the airways.

 

Option C. Prevents overexpansion of the lung: Incorrect, the primary role of surfactant is not to prevent overexpansion but to reduce the energy required to expand the lungs and prevent alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The essential function of surfactant is to reduce the surface tension within the alveoli, preventing their collapse and ensuring efficient lung operation, especially in the prevention of conditions like Infant Respiratory Distress Syndrome in premature infants.

questions.text: Identify the hormones A & B giving negative feedback on Hypothalamus – pituitary axis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inhibin and Testosterone

 

In the diagram, you can see that hormone A is produced by Sertoli cells and hormone B is produced by Leydig cells. In the male reproductive system:

 

Inhibin (A), produced by Sertoli cells within the seminiferous tubules of the testes, specifically inhibits the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland.

 

Testosterone (B), produced by Leydig cells, exerts negative feedback on both the hypothalamus to inhibit the release of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) and on the anterior pituitary to decrease the secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) and FSH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrogen and Progesterone: These are primarily female sex hormones involved in the female reproductive cycle and do not provide negative feedback in the male reproductive axis as represented in the diagram.

 

Option C. Cortisol and Aldosterone: These hormones are involved in the stress response and electrolyte balance, respectively, and are part of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Option D. Thyroxine and Triiodothyronine: These thyroid hormones exert negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis, not the reproductive axis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin and Testosterone are the hormones produced by Sertoli and Leydig cells, respectively, that provide negative feedback on the hypothalamus-pituitary axis in the male reproductive system.

questions.text: In a fetal monitoring, which of the following factors primarily contributes to an increase in fetal heart rate acceleration during labor and delivery, signifying fetal well-being? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

The carotid body chemoreceptors play a crucial role in monitoring and responding to changes in blood oxygen levels, particularly during labor and delivery. These receptors are highly sensitive to decreases in blood oxygen levels (hypoxia) and increases in carbon dioxide levels (hypercapnia). When activated, they send signals to the brainstem to increase respiratory rate and heart rate, thereby ensuring adequate oxygen supply to the fetus.

 

During labor, the fetus can experience transient periods of hypoxia due to contractions and reduced placental blood flow. The carotid body chemoreceptors detect these changes and contribute to fetal heart rate acceleration, which is an important indicator of fetal well-being.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Aortic baroreceptors: Incorrect. Aortic baroreceptors are primarily involved in regulating blood pressure by detecting changes in arterial pressure and activate cardio-vagal (Parasympathetic) center. Their activation leads to reduction in fetal heart rate (not acceleration).

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: Incorrect. While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall cardiovascular regulation, the direct response to hypoxia and resulting heart rate acceleration is mediated by chemoreceptors.

 

Option D. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): Incorrect. ANP is involved in regulating blood volume and pressure by promoting sodium and water excretion, but it does not directly influence fetal heart rate acceleration during labor.

 

Educational Objective

 

Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen levels and contributing to fetal heart rate acceleration during labor, indicating fetal well-being.

questions.text: Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic picture of muscle? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha actinin

 

The image shows a sarcomere and the arrow marks the Z line which is constituted by Alpha actinin.

 

The orderly arrangement of actin, myosin, and related proteins that produces this pattern. The area between two Z-lines is called sarcomere.

 

 

  • Each muscle fiber contains several hundred to several thousand myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril is composed of about 1500 adjacent myosin filaments and 3000 actin filaments.
  • The thick filaments are myosin, and the thin filaments are actin
  • The myosin and actin filaments partially interdigitate and thus cause the myofibrils to have alternate light and dark bands.
  • The light bands contain only actin filaments and are called I bands because they are isotropic to polarized light.
  • The dark bands contain myosin filaments, as well as the ends of the actin filaments where they overlap the myosin, and are called A bands because they are anisotropic to polarized light.
  • Small projections from the sides of the myosin filaments are cross-bridges. The interaction between these cross-bridges and the actin filaments that causes contraction.
  • The ends of the actin filaments are attached to a so-called Z disc. From this disc, these filaments extend in both directions to interdigitate with the myosin filaments.
  • The Z disc is composed of filamentous proteins different from the actin and myosin filaments, passes
  • crosswise across the myofibril and also crosswise from myofibril to myofibril, attaching the myofibrils to one another all the way across the muscle fiber. Therefore, the entire muscle fiber has light and dark bands, as do the individual myofibrils giving the skeletal and cardiac muscle their striated appearance.
  • The portion of the myofibril (or of the whole muscle fibre) that lies between two successive Z discs is called a sarcomere.

 

Note: Some sources say that even titin is a component of Z-disc so if alpha actinin is not given in the options titin is the second-best answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: A thin filament protein that interacts with myosin for muscle contraction but is not specific to the Z line.

 

Option C. Titin: A large elastic protein that spans from the Z line to the M line, providing elasticity and stabilizing the sarcomere's structure. Although titin is associated with the Z line, alpha actinin is the primary constituent.

 

Option D. Tropomyosin: A protein that lies along the actin filament and regulates muscle contraction by controlling access to the myosin-binding sites on actin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Z line in a sarcomere is primarily constituted by alpha actinin, which plays a critical role in anchoring actin filaments and maintaining the structural integrity of the muscle fiber.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with polydipsia. Which of the following conditions would NOT typically cause increased thirst in this patient? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) SIADH

 

Explanation:

 

  • SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate ADH Secretion) causes decreased thirst because:  
    • It leads to decreased plasma osmolality
    • Increases blood volume
    • Results in dilutional hyponatremia
    • Suppresses thirst mechanism via hypothalamic osmoreceptors

       

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Diabetes Insipidus: Causes increased thirst due to inability to concentrate urine, leading to high plasma osmolality

 

Option C. Psychogenic polydipsia: Primary excessive water intake due to psychiatric conditions, leading to compensatory polyuria

 

Option D. Acute blood loss: Triggers thirst via: 

  • Decreased blood volume
  • Baroreceptor activation
  • Increased angiotensin II
  • Activation of renin-angiotensin system

 

This question tests understanding of pathophysiological mechanisms that both increase and decrease thirst, particularly focusing on conditions that affect osmolarity and volume status.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

To understand the physiological and pathological conditions affecting thirst mechanism, particularly differentiating between conditions that increase versus decrease thirst sensation.

questions.text:
Calculate the ECF volume in a volunteer in whom 10 gm of mannitol was injected in venous blood. At equilibrium urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was 65 mg/100 ml?

In a volunteer, 10 grams of mannitol was injected into the venous blood. At equilibrium, the urinary excretion of mannitol was found to be 10% and the plasma concentration of mannitol was measured at 65 mg/100 ml. Calculate the extracellular fluid (ECF) volume based on this information. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 14L

 

ECF volume of the above volunteer is calculated to be 14 L.

 

Mannitol is a marker of ECF volume as it does not cross the cell membrane and remains in the ECF.

 

The ECF volume can be calculated using the formula:

 

 

Where,

 

  • V = ECF volume
  • Amount injected = 10 gm
  • Amount of mannitol excreted = 10% of 10 gm = 1gm

  • Plasma concentration of mannitol = 65 mg/100mL = 0.65 gm/L

     

Calculation:

 

ECF Volume = (10-1) /0.65 = 13.8 L = approximately 14 L

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extracellular fluid (ECF) volume can be calculated by using the dilution principle, taking into account the amount of marker substance injected, the amount excreted, and the plasma concentration of the marker.

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.text: Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes which of the following?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

 

Explanation

 

Lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of pons causes loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side.

 

The first order neurons carry sensory information regarding touch, proprioception or vibration from the peripheral nerves to the medulla oblongata by two different pathways 

 

  • Signals from the upper limb (T6 and above) – travel in the fasciculus cuneatus (the lateral part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus cuneatus of the medulla oblongata.
  • Signals from the lower limb (below T6) – travel in the fasciculus gracilis (the medial part of the dorsal column). They then synapse in the nucleus gracilis of the medulla oblongata.

 

The second order neuron begin in the cuneate nucleus or gracilis. The fibres receive the information from the preceding neuron, and delivers it to the third order neuron in the thalamus. Within the medulla oblongata, these fibres decussate (cross to the other side of the CNS). They then travel in the contralateral medial lemniscus to reach the thalamus.

 

Lastly, the third order neuron transmit the sensory signals from the thalamus to the ipsilateral primary sensory cortex of the brain. They ascend from the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus, travel through the internal capsule and terminate at the sensory cortex.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain and temperature loss in the same side: Incorrect, as the medial lemniscus does not primarily carry pain and temperature sensations; these are transmitted by the spinothalamic tract.

 

Option B. Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side: Incorrect for the same reason as above.

 

Option C. Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side: Incorrect because the crossing of fibers in the medulla means that a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the pons affects the opposite side of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons causes loss of tactile sense and proprioception on the opposite side of the body due to the decussation (crossing over) of second-order neurons in the medulla, which then ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus to the brain.

choices.text: A, B, C, D
A, C, D

questions.text:
Which of the following can be used to calculate the cardiac output? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. ECHO.
  2. Ventilation-perfusion scan.
  3. Thermodilution.
  4. Fick's principle
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A, C, D

 

Fick principle, thermodilution, and ECHO can be used to measure cardiac output.

 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

 

Option A. Doppler echocardiography is a method for detecting the direction and velocity of moving blood within the heart. This is also a popular method to measure cardiac output.

 

Option C. Thermodilution method - a known volume of cold sterile solution is injected into the right atrium via inferior vena cava by using a catheter. Cardiac output is measured by determining the resultant change in the blood temperature in pulmonary artery. For this purpose, two thermistors (temperature transducers) are used. One of them is placed in the inferior vena cava and the second one is placed in pulmonary artery. A pulmonary artery catheter is used to place the thermistors in their positions.

 

Option D. The Fick principle, as applied to cardiac output, relies on the recognition that the total uptake of oxygen by the peripheral tissues is equal to the product of the blood flow to the peripheral tissues and the arterial-venous oxygen concentration difference.

Formula:

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Indirect methods used to measure cardiac output:

 

  1. By using Fick principle
  2. Indicator (dye) dilution technique
  3. Thermodilution technique
  4. Ultrasonic Doppler transducer technique
  5. Doppler echocardiography
  6. Ballisto cardiography.

choices.text: All of the above

questions.text: Which of the following is an Orexinergic hormone? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ghrelin

 

Explanation

 

  • Ghrelin is an orexinergic hormone primarily produced in the stomach. It plays a significant role in stimulating appetite and promoting food intake by activating orexin neurons in the hypothalamus. Orexinergic hormones are those that activate orexin receptors, which are involved in the regulation of sleep-wake cycles and feeding behaviors.

 

Orexinergic System

 

  • The orexinergic system includes hormones and neurotransmitters that affect the orexin receptors in the brain. Ghrelin is specifically known for its role in increasing hunger and is sometimes referred to as the "hunger hormone."
  • It also influences the secretion of growth hormone and insulin, and it has a broader role in energy balance and metabolic processes.
  • Some examples of orexigenic hormones:
    • Ghrelin - Increases food intake (Hormones hunger), Growth hormone secretion, Increases insulin secretion.
    • Orexin - produced by the hypothalamus and is involved in regulating sleep and appetite. Neuropeptide Y (NPY) and Agouti-related peptide (AgRP), can also stimulate appetite and promote food intake.
    • Dysregulation of these hormones can contribute to conditions such as obesity and eating disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testosterone: Incorrect as testosterone is a steroid hormone primarily involved in the development and maintenance of male sexual characteristics and reproductive functions.

 

Option C. Progesterone: Incorrect because progesterone is a steroid hormone involved in the menstrual cycle, pregnancy, and embryogenesis of humans and other species.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect as only ghrelin among the listed options functions as an orexinergic hormone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ghrelin is the correct answer as it is the only hormone among the options that is classified as orexinergic, playing a critical role in stimulating appetite and regulating energy balance through its interaction with orexin neurons in the brain. This mechanism is pivotal in understanding metabolic disorders and targets for obesity treatment.

choices.text: Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord

questions.text: A patient has recurrent optic neuritis of both eyes with extensive transverse myelitis. Visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60 and visual acuity in the left eye 6/18. The patient showed a partial response to steroids. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neuromyelitis optica

 

Bilateral optic neuritis with extensive transverse myelitis and partial steroid response is suggestive of NMO-Spectrum disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MS usually causes U/L optic neuritis. LETM (Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis) not common in MS.

 

Option C. SACD usually affects the posterior column. LETM, optic neuritis not a feature of B12 deficiency.

 

Option D. Neurosyphilis is usually associated with RAPD (U/L Optic neuritis). LETM not common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINGERCHUK Criteria for NMO-SD

choices.text: A - Somatostatin B - GH C - GHRH D - IGF1
A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1
A - IGF1 B - GHRH C - GH D - Somatostatin
A - GHRH B - Somatostatin C - GH D - IGF1

questions.text: Identify the hormones represented by the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Somatostatin B - GHRH C - GH D - IGF1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Somatostatin (Growth Hormone Inhibitory Hormone, GHIH): Somatostatin is released from the hypothalamus and acts as an inhibitory hormone, suppressing the secretion of GH from the pituitary gland.

 

B. Growth Hormone Releasing Hormone (GHRH): GHRH stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone.

 

C. Growth Hormone (GH): GH is released from the somatotrophs of the anterior pituitary gland and has a direct effect on tissues.

 

D. Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF1): IGF1 is produced in the liver in response to GH and mediates many of the growth-promoting effects of GH, representing the indirect effects of GH.

 

The hypothalamus, often referred to as the "master gland," orchestrates this hormonal cascade by releasing both inhibitory and stimulatory hormones that regulate the secretion of GH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sequence of hormonal regulation in growth hormone release is: Somatostatin (inhibitory) and GHRH (stimulatory) from the hypothalamus regulate GH release from the pituitary, which in turn stimulates IGF1 production in the liver.

choices.text: Tissue factor

questions.text: Which of the following clotting factors would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Factor 2

 

Explanation

 

Factor 2 would have decreased gamma carboxyglutamate residue in a patient on warfarin therapy.

 

Factors II, VII, IX, X are vitamin k dependent coagulation factors, as their activated by carboxylation of their glutamate residues by enzyme y-glutamyl carboxylase requires vitamin K (reduced form) as a co-factor.

 

This reduced form of vitamin K is constantly oxidized for the reaction to continue. This recycling is done by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme is inhibited by warfarin. Thus, warfarin affects vitamin k dependent factors.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Factor 11: Incorrect, Factor XI is not vitamin K-dependent and thus not directly affected by warfarin therapy.

 

Option C. Tissue factor: Incorrect, Tissue factor (Factor III) is a different component of the clotting cascade that acts as a receptor and cofactor for Factor VIIa; it is not a vitamin K-dependent factor and is not affected by warfarin.

 

Option D. Factor 5: Incorrect, Factor V is not dependent on vitamin K for its function, so its activity is not diminished by warfarin therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin therapy impacts the function of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors by inhibiting the recycling of vitamin K, crucial for the carboxylation of these factors. Factor 2 (prothrombin) is one of these affected factors, leading to a reduction in its clotting ability in the presence of warfarin, which is utilized therapeutically to prevent thrombosis.

questions.text: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) shows increased peripheral chemoreceptor sensitivity. Which ion channel's influx is primarily responsible for neurotransmitter release in these receptors during hypoxia? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ca2+

 

Explanation: 

 

In peripheral chemoreceptors (carotid and aortic bodies), the response to hypoxia involves a cascade of events. While K+ channels are oxygen-sensitive and initiate the process, the actual release of neurotransmitters is primarily dependent on the influx of calcium ions (Ca2+). When oxygen levels drop:

  1. O2-sensitive K+ channels close
  2. This leads to membrane depolarization
  3. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels open
  4. Ca2+ influx triggers neurotransmitter release

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+: While sodium channels contribute to membrane depolarization, they are not the primary ion responsible for neurotransmitter release in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Option B. K+: Potassium channels are oxygen-sensitive and their closure initiates the process, but they don't directly trigger neurotransmitter release.

 

Option D. Cl-: Chloride ions maintain cellular homeostasis but are not directly involved in the neurotransmitter release mechanism in peripheral chemoreceptors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the complete cascade of events in peripheral chemoreceptor activation is crucial. While K+ channels are the oxygen sensors, Ca2+ influx is the final mediator responsible for neurotransmitter release during hypoxia.

questions.text: A man comes to the OPD with complaints of sinusitis and breathing difficulty. He also gives a history of infertility for the past few years. On further examination, thoracic cavity organs were found to be on the opposite side. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome


Kartagener syndrome is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (a condition where the thoracic and abdominal organs are mirrored from their normal positions).

 

The underlying cause of Kartagener syndrome is a defect in the structure and function of cilia, which are hair-like structures that line the respiratory tract and other parts of the body. These cilia are responsible for moving mucus and other substances along the respiratory tract, as well as for ensuring proper placement of organs during embryonic development.

 

In this case, the patient's symptoms of sinusitis, breathing difficulties, and history of infertility, combined with the finding of situs inversus, strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome. The infertility is due to immotile sperm in males, which is also caused by defective cilia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bronchial asthma: This condition typically presents with recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, and chest tightness. It is not associated with situs inversus or infertility.

 

Option C. Kallmann syndrome: This genetic disorder is characterized by delayed or absent puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It is not associated with situs inversus, sinusitis, or bronchiectasis.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: Although it can cause chronic cough and sinusitis, it is not associated with situs inversus or infertility. Bronchiectasis is a condition where the bronchial tubes are permanently widened, leading to frequent lung infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the presence of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, situs inversus, and infertility, all of which result from defective ciliary function.

questions.text: Which of the following is high-molecular weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to integrins? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fibronectin

 

Fibronectin is a high-molecular weight (~500-~600 kDa) glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins called integrins.

 

Integrins are cell surface receptors that play a crucial role in connecting cells to their extracellular environment, including other cells and the extracellular matrix (ECM). Integrins can connect with several types of molecules and proteins, including:

 

  1. Extracellular Matrix (ECM) Proteins: Integrins can bind to various components of the ECM, such as fibronectin, laminin, collagen, and vitronectin. These interactions allow cells to anchor to the ECM and provide structural support.
  2. Cell Adhesion Molecules: Integrins can connect with other cell adhesion molecules on neighbouring cells, promoting cell-cell interactions and the formation of multicellular structures. Examples of cell adhesion molecules include cadherins, selectins, and immunoglobulin superfamily proteins.
  3. Signalling Proteins: Integrins can also associate with intracellular signalling proteins, such as focal adhesion kinases (FAK), Src family kinases, and various adapter proteins. These interactions transmit signals from the ECM to the cell's interior, influencing cellular processes like cell growth, migration, and differentiation.
  4. Blood Clotting Factors: In platelets, integrins can bind to fibrinogen and von Willebrand factor, contributing to platelet aggregation and blood clot formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cadherin: Involved in calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion.

 

Option B. Vitronectin: Also a part of the extracellular matrix but known for its role in serum spreading factor and in the promotion of cell adhesion and spreading.

 

Option D. Selectin: Plays a role in cell adhesion during the immune response, particularly in the binding of white blood cells to the endothelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibronectin is a key component of the extracellular matrix that interacts with cell surface integrins to mediate various cellular processes including adhesion, migration, and tissue repair.

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47°C. What is the mechanism of heat loss? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweating

 

The mechanism of heat loss in the given case is sweating.

 

As long as skin temperature is greater than the temperature of the surroundings, heat can be lost by radiation and conduction. But when the temperature of the surroundings becomes greater than that of the skin, instead of losing heat, the body gains heat by both radiation and conduction. Under these conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself of heat is by evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation and B. Conduction are effective when the ambient temperature is lower than the body's skin temperature. However, at temperatures higher than the skin temperature, these methods can result in heat gain rather than heat loss.

 

Option C. Convection can aid in heat loss if the air movement can cool the skin, but at high environmental temperatures, its effectiveness is limited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high environmental temperatures, the body relies primarily on sweating and evaporation to lose heat and regulate body temperature effectively.

choices.text: Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume
Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve
Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption
Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with dyspnea and chest pain. Which of the following proves that she has aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in myocardial oxygen consumption is seen with increased pressure work than volume

 

In cases of aortic stenosis, the primary issue is the increased afterload due to the obstruction in the aortic valve, which forces the left ventricle to work harder to push blood against the increased resistance. This increased pressure work leads to higher myocardial oxygen consumption because the heart needs more energy to overcome the obstruction. The increase in pressure work (afterload) is significantly more in aortic stenosis than in aortic regurgitation, where volume overload (preload) is more prominent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aortic stenosis causes reduced pressure at the aortic valve: This statement is incorrect because aortic stenosis actually increases the pressure at the aortic valve due to the obstruction, not reduces it.

 

Option C. Workload has nothing to do with myocardial oxygen consumption: This is incorrect. Myocardial oxygen consumption is directly related to the workload of the heart. Increased workload, especially due to pressure overload in conditions like aortic stenosis, results in higher oxygen consumption.

 

Option D. Increased pressure - Increase in preload more than afterload: This is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the afterload (pressure) is more significantly increased than the preload. Preload (end-diastolic volume) is typically increased in conditions like aortic regurgitation, not aortic stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic stenosis is characterized by increased pressure work (afterload) leading to higher myocardial oxygen consumption, distinguishing it from aortic regurgitation, which is associated with volume overload (preload).

choices.text: Central capillary dilatation → Wheal → Surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare.

questions.text: On performing a Histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare

 

In patient with brachial plexus trunk injury, there is anesthesia over the skin in that region. Histamine test in this patient will result in capillary dilatation and wheal without surrounding flare.

 

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin which includes a red reaction, flare and wheal.

 

  • Red reaction is because of capillary dilatation and is independent of innervation.
  • Flare reaction is due to dilatation of arterioles caused by the axon reflex.
  • Axon reflex or antidromic reflex is the process by which the impulses are conducted in a direction opposite to the normal direction. Normally, the impulses produced by a cutaneous pain receptor pass through sensory nerve fiber towards the nerve cell body in posterior nerve root ganglion. Some of these impulses pass through the other branches of the same fiber in the opposite direction and reach the blood vessels supplied by these branches. Impulses now dilate the blood vessels. This is called the antidromic or axon reflex. Thus, flare is absent in anesthetized skin.
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to increased capillary permeability

 

The triple response can be seen after total sympathectomy

 

The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a brachial plexus trunk injury, the histamine test will result in central capillary dilatation and a wheal without the surrounding flare due to the disruption of the axon reflex.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions causes increased GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased renal perfusion / RPF

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is the rate at which blood is filtered in the kidneys. Several factors can influence GFR, including arteriolar resistance, arteriolar dilation, hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule, and renal perfusion.

 

Increased renal perfusion / RPF: Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) enhances the blood flow into the kidneys and consequently increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries. This increase in pressure promotes filtration and increases GFR. Therefore, increased renal perfusion leads to an increased GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Afferent arteriolar resistance: Increasing afferent arteriolar resistance constricts the inlet to the glomerulus, decreasing renal plasma flow and hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, which reduces GFR.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar dilation: Dilation of the efferent arteriole reduces resistance to blood flow out of the glomerulus, lowering hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries and decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increased pressure in Bowman's capsule counteracts the filtration pressure, reducing the net filtration pressure and decreasing GFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, thereby increasing the GFR

choices.text: Subthalamic nuclei
Globus pallidus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffered from a stroke 2 days ago. He now presents with involuntary, violent, and flinging movements of the limbs on one side. What is the likely site of lesion in this patient?   (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Subthalamic nuclei

 

Explanation

 

Most probable diagnosis as per the clinical history is hemiballismus which is caused by a lesion in subthalamic nuclei.

 

Hemiballismus is a disorder characterized by violent involuntary abnormal movements on one side of the body involving mostly the arm. While walking, the arm swings widely. These movements are called the flinging movements. These movements are due to the release phenomenon because of the absence of inhibitory influence on movements. Hemiballismus occurs due to degeneration of subthalamic nucleus of Luys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: Incorrect for hemiballismus. Lesions here typically result in different forms of dyskinesia, such as parkinsonism or dystonia, but not hemiballismus.

 

Option C. Putamen: Also incorrect for this symptom. While putamen lesions are involved in many movement disorders, like Huntington's disease and some forms of Parkinson's disease, they do not typically cause hemiballismus.

 

Option D. Caudate nucleus: Incorrect. Lesions in the caudate nucleus are more often associated with Huntington's disease, which leads to chorea—rapid, jerky movements—not the large-amplitude flinging movements seen in hemiballismus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with unilateral flinging, violent limb movements following a stroke, the subthalamic nuclei should be considered as the primary site of lesion. This knowledge is crucial for accurate diagnosis and guiding treatment decisions, such as the use of neuroleptics or other interventions to control these disruptive movements.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors occurs due to prolonged exposure to elevated vasopressin levels resulting in excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels, thus maintaining euvolemia and preventing excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. This is called as vasopressin escape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in urine osmolarity: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape does not result in an increase in urine osmolarity. Instead, it is characterized by the body's ability to excrete free water to prevent hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Decrease in ADH secretion: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape occurs despite high levels of ADH, not due to a decrease in ADH secretion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Incorrect. The condition involves the downregulation, not upregulation, of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH): Pathogenesis and clinical findings

questions.text: In a febrile patient, comparing stages X and Z as shown in the temperature curve, which mechanism is specifically activated in stage Z? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sweating

 

Explanation: 

 

In the temperature curve shown:

 

  • Stage X represents the crisis/peak fever stage where body temperature matches the elevated set point
  • Stage Z represents the defervescence phase where the body actively works to reduce temperature to the new lower set point
  • During stage Z, sweating is specifically activated as a key cooling mechanism to facilitate heat loss

 

The comparison between stages X and Z shows the transition from peak fever to temperature normalization:

 

  • Stage X: Temperature matches elevated set point, no active cooling mechanisms
  • Stage Z: Active cooling through sweating to achieve new lower set point

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasoconstriction:

  • Vasoconstriction occurs during the initial fever rise (stage W)
  • In stage Z, vasodilation (not vasoconstriction) occurs to promote heat loss

 

Option C. Shivering:

  • Shivering is activated during stage W when temperature needs to rise
  • It's inhibited during stage Z when the body needs to cool down

 

Option D. Increased metabolic rate:

  • Metabolic rate increases during fever onset (stage W)
  • During stage Z, metabolic rate decreases to help reduce heat production

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding the temporal sequence and specific mechanisms of fever defervescence is crucial. While multiple cooling mechanisms are activated when fever breaks, sweating is a key active process during the temperature normalization phase.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parathyroid adenoma

 

Parathyroid adenoma is not a cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition in which the parathyroid glands produce excess parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to a stimulus other than low blood calcium levels. This can occur in response to various conditions that cause chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or exposure to certain medications such as lithium.

 

Parathyroid adenoma, on the other hand, is a cause of primary hyperparathyroidism, which is characterized by excess PTH secretion due to an abnormality within the parathyroid gland itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lithium intake: Lithium can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism by impairing calcium sensing.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency is a well-known cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its role in calcium absorption.

 

Option D. Chronic kidney disease: CKD is a major cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism due to its effects on phosphate and vitamin D metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parathyroid adenoma causes primary hyperparathyroidism, whereas secondary hyperparathyroidism is due to external stimuli such as chronic kidney disease, vitamin D deficiency, or lithium intake.

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30-300 seconds

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, hence of the given 4 options, 30-300 seconds is the most appropriate answer.

 

Common classification of memories that divides memories into

 

  1. Short-term memory, which includes memories that last for seconds or at most minutes unless they are converted into longer-term memories 
  2. Intermediate long-term memories, which last for days to weeks but then fade away
  3. Long-term memory, which, once stored, can be recalled up to years or even a lifetime later.

 

“working memory,” that includes mainly short-term memory that is used during the course of intellectual reasoning but is terminated as each stage of the problem is resolved.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, storing information temporarily before it is either forgotten or encoded into long-term memory.

 

Additional Information 

 

Memories are frequently classified according to the type of information that is stored. 

 

1. Declarative memory basically means memory of the various details of an integrated thought, such as memory of an important experience that includes – 

  1. Memory of the surroundings, 
  2. Memory of time relationships, 
  3. Memory of causes of the experience, 
  4. Memory of the meaning of the experience, and 
  5. Memory of one’s deductions that were left in the person’s mind.
     

2. Skill memory is frequently associated with motor activities of the person’s body, such as all the skills developed for hitting a tennis ball, including automatic memories to 

  1. Sight the ball, 
  2. Calculate the relationship and speed of the ball to the racquet, and 
  3. Deduce rapidly the motions of the body, the arms, and the racquet required to hit the ball as desired.

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Substances and the type of transport across a membrane are given below, choose the correct combination: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple diffusion
  2. Glucose: Facilitated diffusion
  3. Sodium: Voltage-gated channel
  4. Sodium: Secondary active transport
  5. Calcium: Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct

 

All the given combinations are correct for the types of transport across a membrane:

 

1. Oxygen. Simple diffusion: Oxygen is a non-polar molecule and diffuses directly across the lipid bilayer of cell membranes by simple diffusion. This process does not require any membrane proteins or energy input.

 

2. Glucose. Facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported into cells via facilitated diffusion, which involves specific carrier proteins (such as GLUT transporters). This process allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient without the use of energy.

 

3. Sodium. Voltage-gated channel: Voltage-gated sodium channels are integral membrane proteins that open and close in response to changes in membrane potential. These channels allow the selective passage of sodium ions during the action potentials in neurons and muscle cells.

 

4. Sodium. Secondary active transport: Sodium ions are also involved in secondary active transport, where the movement of sodium down its electrochemical gradient (established by primary active transport) drives the transport of another substance against its gradient. An example is the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT).

 

5. Calcium. Active transport: Calcium ions are actively transported across cell membranes using ATP-driven pumps such as the Ca²⁺-ATPase (also known as the calcium pump). This process maintains low intracellular calcium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the mentioned substances and their associated transport mechanisms are correct: Oxygen via simple diffusion, glucose via facilitated diffusion, sodium via voltage-gated channels and secondary active transport, and calcium via active transport.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

choices.text: Air in lung after normal expiration
Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration
Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration
Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration

questions.text: Which of the following best defines vital capacity? (NEET pg 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Maximum air that can be expired after maximum inspiration

 

Explanation:


Vital capacity (VC) is defined as the maximum amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. It represents the sum of tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV). In healthy adults, VC typically measures around 3.5 L, though this varies based on factors like gender, age, and body size.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option a. Air in lung after normal expiration This definition describes Functional Residual Capacity (FRC), which equals ERV + RV (approximately 2.5 L). FRC represents the volume remaining in the lungs after a normal expiration.
  • Option b. Maximum air that can be expired after normal inspiration This describes Expiratory Reserve Volume (ERV) only, which is approximately 1 L. ERV is just one component of vital capacity.
  • Option d. Maximum air in lung after end of maximal inspiration This defines Total Lung Capacity (TLC), which includes VC plus the residual volume (RV). TLC = IRV + TV + ERV + RV (approximately 5 L).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be expelled from the lungs after a maximum inspiration, representing the sum of IRV, TV, and ERV, and is a key measurement in pulmonary function testing.

choices.text: Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
No exchange of O2 & CO2
CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

questions.text: Va/Q = infinity means? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. No exchange of O2 & CO2

 

Explanation

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

  • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow
  • When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero.
  • When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity.
  • At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero: Incorrect as partial pressure of O2 will be high in the alveoli but without perfusion, no exchange occurs.

 

Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood: Incorrect because without perfusion, there's no blood flow to equilibrate CO2 levels.

 

Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal: Incorrect because, although the partial pressures in the ventilated alveoli might appear normal or even high for O2, without perfusion, these gases are not effectively exchanged with the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ventilation-perfusion (Va/Q) ratio of infinity, indicative of ventilation without perfusion, results in no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) due to the absence of blood flow to the ventilated alveoli. This scenario highlights the critical balance needed between air delivery to the lungs and blood flow through the pulmonary circulation for effective respiratory gas exchange.

questions.text: A patient experiences bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea following the administration of intravenous irritants during a medical procedure. These symptoms are suggestive of a specific reflex response. Which one of the following reflexes is most likely being represented in this scenario? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bezold-Jarisch reflex

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that can be triggered by certain chemical stimuli or intravenous irritants. It is characterized by a triad of bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, due to activation of mechanoreceptors or chemoreceptors in the ventricles, leading to increased parasympathetic (vagal) activity and decreased sympathetic tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bainbridge reflex: Incorrect. The Bainbridge reflex involves an increase in heart rate in response to increased venous return. This reflex does not typically cause bradycardia or hypotension.

 

Option C. Cushing’s reflex: Incorrect. Cushing’s reflex is a physiological nervous system response to increased intracranial pressure, and it typically presents with hypertension (not hypotension), bradycardia, and respiratory depression.

 

Option D. Valsalva maneuver: Incorrect. The Valsalva maneuver involves a voluntary increase in intra-abdominal pressure by exhaling forcefully with a closed glottis. It can affect heart rate and blood pressure but is not a reflex response to intravenous irritants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea in response to certain chemical stimuli or intravenous irritants due to increased vagal activity and decreased sympathetic tone.

questions.text:
What is the sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Pulmonary
  2. Aortic
  3. Mitral
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 ➔ 2 ➔ 3
 

The sequence of cardiac sounds as they're perceived on the left side of the chest, from top to bottom, is outlined below:

 

  1. Pulmonary - detected in the second intercostal space.
  2. Aortic - can be heard at the neoaortic region or Erb's point, situated in the second intercostal space.
  3. Mitral - observed at the fifth intercostal space.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of heart sounds heard from the top to the bottom of the left side of the chest wall is: Pulmonary (second intercostal space), Aortic (second intercostal space), and Mitral (fifth intercostal space).

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular filling

 

The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

 

  • Atrial Heart Sound (Fourth Heart Sound) – Occurs when the atria contract, and presumably, it is caused by the inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

 

Other heart sounds:

 

  • First heart sound – contraction of the ventricles first causes sudden backflow of blood against the A-V valves (the tricuspid and mitral valves) causing them to close producing the first heart sound.
  • The second heart sound results from sudden closure of the semilunar valves at the end of systole.
  • Third Heart Sound – occasionally a weak, rumbling third heart sound is heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. Most probably it is due to oscillation of blood back and forth between the walls of the ventricles initiated by inrushing blood from the atria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by the atrial contraction and the subsequent inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

choices.text: Substance P

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. VIP

 

Explanation

 

VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

 

During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholine: Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.

 

Option C. Substance P: Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: A 28-year-old mountaineer is brought to your emergency department with suspected severe hypothermia (core temperature < 28°C). Which method of temperature measurement would be most appropriate? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal

 

In severe hypothermia (core temperature < 28°C), esophageal temperature measurement is considered the gold standard, as it provides the most accurate core temperature reading due to its proximity to the heart and great vessels. This is particularly important in severe hypothermia where precise temperature monitoring is crucial for management decisions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rectal: Incorrect. While usually reliable for mild-moderate hypothermia, rectal temperatures can lag behind true core temperature changes in severe hypothermia due to peripheral vasoconstriction. Additionally, there may be a significant lag time in reflecting rapid temperature changes during rewarming.

 

Option C. Oral: Incorrect. Oral temperature measurements are unreliable in hypothermia due to peripheral vasoconstriction and the influence of environmental factors. Furthermore, the patient may be unable to hold the thermometer properly if severely hypothermic.

 

Option D. Axillary: Incorrect. Axillary measurements are highly inaccurate in hypothermia due to peripheral vasoconstriction and environmental influence. They can significantly underestimate the true core temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe hypothermia, esophageal temperature monitoring provides the most accurate core temperature measurement due to its anatomical location and ability to detect rapid temperature changes during rewarming procedures.

questions.text: Match the given cellular components with their respective marker enzymes?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C

 

The correct matches of cellular components with their marker enzymes are:

 

  1. Mitochondria - ATP synthase (D): ATP synthase is a key enzyme in the mitochondria involved in the synthesis of ATP, making it a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  2. Peroxisomes - Catalase (A): Catalase is an enzyme found in peroxisomes that helps in the breakdown of hydrogen peroxide, making it a characteristic marker for peroxisomes.
  3. Golgi complex - Galactosyl transferase (B): Galactosyl transferase is involved in the glycosylation processes in the Golgi complex, serving as a marker enzyme for this organelle.
  4. Endoplasmic reticulum - Glucose-6-phosphatase (C): Glucose-6-phosphatase is found in the endoplasmic reticulum and is involved in glucose metabolism, making it a marker enzyme for this structure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Tigroid white matter on MRI imaging is seen in which of the following conditions? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease (PMD) is a rare, genetic, demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by a distinctive "tigroid" pattern on MRI. This pattern arises from the preservation of perivascular myelin in the brain's white matter, interspersed with areas of demyelination, creating a striped or tigroid appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pantothenate kinase deficiency: This condition is also known as PKAN (Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration). It typically shows a characteristic MRI feature known as the "eye of the tiger" sign, which involves a specific pattern of iron deposition in the basal ganglia. The "eye of the tiger" sign appears due to a combination of hyperintense signal surrounded by a region of hypointensity on T2-weighted MRI images, reflecting iron accumulation and gliosis. This is distinct from the tigroid pattern seen in demyelinating diseases.

 

Option B. Neuroferritinopathy: Neuroferritinopathy is another disorder of iron metabolism that affects the brain, leading to iron accumulation, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings in neuroferritinopathy typically do not include the tigroid pattern but may show abnormalities such as signal changes in the basal ganglia related to iron deposition. The imaging features here are more associated with iron accumulation rather than the patchy demyelination that produces the tigroid appearance.

 

Option D. Aceruloplasminemia: Aceruloplasminemia is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by iron accumulation in various tissues, including the brain. Similar to neuroferritinopathy, the primary MRI findings in aceruloplasminemia are related to iron deposition, particularly in the cerebellum and basal ganglia, and do not typically involve the tigroid pattern. Instead, the imaging might show evidence of iron accumulation without the specific changes associated with demyelination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is a prototypical condition that displays a tigroid pattern on MRI. This appearance is due to the patchy preservation and destruction of myelin in the white matter, creating alternating areas of normal myelin and demyelination. This results in the characteristic striped or tigroid appearance on imaging studies, reflective of the disease’s impact on myelination.

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.

 

The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: Asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is due to: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Gibbs Donan reaction

 

The asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane is primarily due to the Gibbs Donan effect. This effect arises from the semi-permeable nature of the cell membrane, which allows certain ions to pass while restricting others. Inside the cell, there are non-diffusible ions such as phosphates and proteins. These non-diffusible ions create an imbalance in the distribution of diffusible ions like potassium (K⁺) and chloride (Cl⁻). The presence of non-diffusible ions inside the cell results in the repulsion of chloride ions and influences the movement of potassium ions, leading to an asymmetrical distribution of ions across the cell membrane. This equilibrium state is referred to as the Gibbs Donan equilibrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na-K with primary active transport: This refers to the sodium-potassium pump (Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase), which actively transports sodium and potassium ions across the cell membrane using energy from ATP. This pump is essential for maintaining the resting membrane potential (RMP) but does not directly contribute to the asymmetrical ion differentiation as it is an active process, not a passive one like the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option C. Na-Cl pump: There is no specific Na-Cl pump involved in the asymmetric distribution of ions. Sodium and chloride ions are transported through different mechanisms, but they do not directly relate to the asymmetrical distribution explained by the Gibbs Donan effect.

 

Option D. Nernst Equilibrium: The Nernst equation calculates the equilibrium potential for a particular ion based on its concentration gradient across the membrane. It helps determine the magnitude of the potential difference but does not explain the asymmetrical distribution of ions itself. The Nernst equilibrium describes a theoretical condition, not the mechanism behind the asymmetrical ion distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs Donan reaction explains the asymmetrical ion differentiation on the cell membrane due to the presence of non-diffusible ions and the semi-permeable nature of the membrane.

questions.text:
Which of the following organelles is absent in the area of the cardiac muscle marked:  
(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lysosome

 

Lysosomes are not typically concentrated in the marked perinuclear area of cardiac muscle cells. Instead, lysosomes are distributed throughout the cytoplasm of the cell. This means that they are present in the cell but do not show a significant concentration or structure in the indicated area of cardiac muscle fibers.

 

In cardiac muscle cells, mitochondria are abundant due to the high-energy demand for contraction, and endoplasmic reticulum (sarcoplasmic reticulum) and Golgi bodies are usually present in the perinuclear area for synthesis and modification of proteins and other important molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria: Mitochondria are highly abundant in cardiac muscle cells, particularly near areas that need significant energy. The heart has a high demand for ATP due to its continuous contractions, and mitochondria are essential for this energy supply.

 

Option C. Golgi bodies: Golgi bodies are present in cardiac muscle cells, often localized around the perinuclear area. They are important for modifying, packaging, and sorting proteins, which are needed in various cellular functions, including those in muscle contraction and maintenance.

 

Option D. Endoplasmic reticulum (ER): The endoplasmic reticulum (or sarcoplasmic reticulum in muscle cells) is crucial for calcium storage and release, which is essential for muscle contraction. It is indeed present in cardiac muscle cells and has a significant role in the regulation of contraction and relaxation cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lysosomes are widely distributed throughout the cytoplasm of cells,

 

  1. Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles 
  2. The enzymes within lysosomes are responsible for breaking down various cellular waste materials, such as proteins, lipids, carbohydrates, and even organelles.
  3. Lysosomes play a crucial role in cellular homeostasis by recycling and eliminating unwanted or damaged cellular components through a process known as autophagy.
  4. The acidic environment within lysosomes (pH around 4.5-5) is necessary for the optimal activity of the digestive enzymes.

 

Lysosomal storage disorders, such as Tay-Sachs disease and Gaucher's disease, occur when there is a malfunction or deficiency of enzymes within lysosomes, leading to the accumulation of undigested materials and subsequent cellular dysfunction.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchi

 

Among the given options, bronchi (medium-sized airway) offer maximum resistance.

 

The best answer here is bronchi, as the other options suggest smaller airways and bronchi is the only medium-sized airway.

 

Since the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series, smallest airway contributes little to overall resistance. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases because the total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high resulting in less resistance. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially because the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

 

Other factors affecting airway resistance:

 

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the trans airway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar duct and C. Respiratory bronchioles: These smaller airways have much lower resistance due to their large total cross-sectional area, which reduces resistance despite their small individual diameters.

 

Option D. Small bronchioles: Similar to the respiratory bronchioles, their high number and extensive branching reduce overall resistance.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bronchi, the medium-sized airways, have the highest airway resistance due to their relatively narrow diameter compared to the total cross-sectional area of smaller airways.

 

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula:

 

 

Where:

 

  • R is the resistance
  • is pie symbol
  • r is radius
  • is viscosity
  • L is length

 

According to Poisuille’s formula, Airway resistance is inversely proportional to the fourth power radius.

 

Poiseuille- Hagen formula suggests that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance.

choices.text: Na+ I- Symporter

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pendrin

 

The transport of iodine within the thyroid gland involves multiple steps, with specific transporters playing distinct roles. The sodium-iodide symporter (Na+ I- Symporter) is responsible for transporting iodine from the bloodstream into the thyroid follicular cells. However, once inside the follicular cells, iodine needs to be transported into the follicular cavity (colloid) where thyroid hormone synthesis occurs. This specific transport is carried out by the protein Pendrin, a chloride-iodide transporter. Pendrin moves iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid, facilitating the next steps of thyroid hormone production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Na+ I- Symporter: This symporter is involved in the initial uptake of iodine from the bloodstream into the follicular cells, not in the transport of iodine into the colloid.

 

Option C. Calmodulin: Calmodulin is a calcium-binding messenger protein, and it does not play a direct role in the transport of iodine within the thyroid gland.

 

Option D. Claudin: Claudin proteins are involved in the formation of tight junctions in cells and do not have a role in the transport of iodine for thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pendrin is the transporter responsible for moving iodine from the follicular cells into the colloid of the thyroid gland, a crucial step in thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: GFR is increased by all except? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureteric stone

 

Ureteric stone causes a reduction in glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Ureteral obstruction decreases glomerular filtration rate (GR) due to a reduction in a single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (SNGFR) and a reduced number of filtering nephrons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased renal blood flow: Correct. Increased renal blood flow increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar constriction: Correct. Efferent arteriolar constriction increases GFR by increasing glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure.

 

Option D. Decreased oncotic pressure: Correct. Decreased oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries increases GFR by reducing the opposing colloid osmotic pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Tracheal innermost layer has which epithelial lining? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified columnar epithelium

 

The trachea, or windpipe, is lined with a specific type of epithelium designed to protect and facilitate the movement of mucus. The innermost layer of the trachea consists of pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to have multiple layers (strata) because the cells' nuclei are at different levels, giving a false impression of stratification (hence "pseudo"). However, it is actually a single layer of cells.

 

Pseudostratified columnar epithelium primarily consists of tall, column-like cells that are closely packed together. Despite appearing layered due to the varying positions of the nuclei, it is a single layer of cells. This structure is crucial for the trachea as it often contains cilia (tiny hair-like projections) and goblet cells that produce mucus. The cilia help move mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, aiding in keeping the airways clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of flat, thin cells and is usually found in areas where rapid diffusion or filtration is required, such as the alveoli in the lungs. It is not suitable for the trachea, which needs a more robust lining to handle mucus and cilia.
