Option B. Ciliary epithelium: While the pseudostratified columnar epithelium in the trachea does contain ciliated cells, "ciliary epithelium" itself is not a distinct classification of epithelial tissue. Therefore, this option is incorrect as a type of epithelial lining.

 

Option D. Cuboidal epithelium: This type of epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells and is generally found in glandular tissues or ducts (like kidney tubules). It is not found lining the trachea, as it lacks the specialized structure needed for mucus movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The innermost layer of the trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar epithelium, which appears layered due to the positioning of cell nuclei but is actually a single layer of cells designed to protect the respiratory tract and facilitate mucus movement.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones do not act on the pancreas? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gastrin

 

Gastrin does not act upon the pancreas. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth.

 

 

Other Options:  

 

Option A. Secretin is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of acidic chyme. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice, which helps neutralize the acidity of the chyme entering the small intestine.

 

Option C. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of fats and proteins. It stimulates the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes, including pancreatic amylase, lipase, and proteases, which aid in the digestion of fats, carbohydrates, and proteins.

 

Option D. GIP (Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide), also known as gastric inhibitory polypeptide, is released by the small intestine in response to the presence of nutrients, particularly glucose and fat. While its primary role is to stimulate the release of insulin from pancreatic beta cells in response to elevated blood glucose levels, it also indirectly influences the pancreas by enhancing the release of pancreatic enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrin does not act on the pancreas. Instead, it stimulates gastric acid secretion and gastric mucosal growth, while Secretin, CCK, and GIP have direct or indirect actions on the pancreas.

choices.text: Located in the thick muscle layer
Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch
Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about baroreceptors? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Located in the thick muscle layer

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer of the carotid bulb of the internal carotid artery (not in the thick muscle layer); where the walls are typically thinner to allow for the detection of pressure changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stretch receptors: Baroreceptors are indeed stretch receptors; they respond to the stretching of the arterial wall as blood pressure changes.

 

Option C. Afferent fibers pass via the glossopharyngeal nerve branch: Afferent fibers from the carotid sinus baroreceptors pass through the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) to the brainstem.

 

Option D. Sensitive to changes in arterial pressure: Baroreceptors are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure; they quickly respond to fluctuations in blood pressure by sending signals to the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Baroreceptors are located in the adventitial layer, not in the thick muscle layer, and they are sensitive to changes in arterial pressure, functioning as stretch receptors with afferent fibers passing via the glossopharyngeal nerve.`1

choices.text: Vagal output to cardiac fibres increase

questions.text: Which of the following events occur immediately when a person changes his/her posture from supine to standing? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decrease in firing from baroreceptor

 

When a person changes posture from supine to standing, the immediate effect is a decrease in mean arterial pressure (MAP) due to gravity causing blood to pool in the lower extremities. This results in decreased venous return and cardiac output and decreased firing from the baroreceptors.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vagal output to cardiac fibers increase: Incorrect. The vagal (parasympathetic) output decreases when standing to allow an increase in heart rate and cardiac output.

 

Option C. Mesenteric vasoconstriction: Incorrect. Although mesenteric vasoconstriction occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is not the immediate response; the initial response is the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Option D. Increase cardiac contractility: Incorrect. While increased cardiac contractility occurs due to sympathetic activation, it is a subsequent response following the decrease in baroreceptor firing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate response when a person changes posture from supine to standing is a decrease in baroreceptor firing due to a reduction in mean arterial pressure.

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Length-tension relationship

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by length-tension relationship.

 

Frank-Starling mechanism states that the greater the heart muscle is stretched during filling, the greater is the force of contraction and the greater the quantity of blood pumped into the aorta or, stated another way: Within physiologic limits, the heart pumps all the blood that returns to it by the way of the veins.

 

When an extra amount of blood flows into the ventricles, the cardiac muscle itself is stretched to greater length. This in turn causes the muscle to contract with increased force because the actin and myosin filaments are brought to a more nearly optimal degree of overlap for force generation. Therefore, the ventricle, because of its increased pumping, automatically pumps the extra blood into the arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume in the heart is best described by the length-tension relationship, which underlies the Frank-Starling mechanism. This principle explains how increased filling of the heart leads to greater contraction force and increased stroke volume.

questions.text: Phase zero of the cardiac action potential in Purkinje fibers is primarily due to which of the following? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium influx

 

In Purkinje fibers, Phase 0 (rapid depolarization) is primarily mediated by fast voltage-gated sodium channels. The rapid influx of sodium ions through these channels causes the membrane potential to become rapidly positive, creating the characteristic steep upstroke of the action potential.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium influx: Incorrect. While calcium influx does occur during the action potential in Purkinje fibers, it primarily contributes to Phase 2 (plateau phase) rather than Phase 0. This is different from nodal tissue where calcium is responsible for Phase 0.

 

Option C. Potassium influx: Incorrect. Potassium channels are primarily involved in repolarization, and potassium typically moves out of rather than into the cell during the cardiac action potential.

 

Option D. Potassium efflux: Incorrect. While potassium efflux does occur during the cardiac action potential, it is primarily responsible for Phase 3 (repolarization) and not Phase 0.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Understanding that Phase 0 of the cardiac action potential in Purkinje fibers is mediated by fast sodium channels, unlike in nodal tissue where it is calcium-dependent. This difference accounts for the faster conduction velocity in Purkinje fibers compared to nodal tissue.

questions.text: Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) is used to relieve pain. What is the mechanism behind it? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gate control theory

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief is based on the gate theory of pain.

 

According to gate control theory, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.

 

TENS activates a complex neuronal network using electrodes to result in a reduction in pain. At frequencies and intensities used clinically, TENS activates large diameter afferent fibers. This afferent input is sent to the central nervous system to activate descending inhibitory systems to reduce hyperalgesia. Specifically, blockade of neuronal activity in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), rostral ventromedial medulla (RVM) and spinal cord inhibit the analgesic effects of TENS showing that TENS analgesia is maintained through these pathways.

 

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Conditioned pain modulation: This refers to the phenomenon where pain in one part of the body can reduce pain in another part, which is not directly related to the mechanism of TENS.

 

Option C. Descending inhibition: While TENS does activate descending inhibitory pathways, the primary mechanism described in the context of TENS for this question is the gate control theory.

 

Option D. Central inhibition: This refers to the inhibition of pain at the level of the central nervous system, which is a broader concept and not specific to the primary mechanism of TENS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) alleviates pain primarily through the gate control theory, which involves blocking pain signals at the spinal cord level by activating large-diameter afferent fibers.

choices.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury and his serum K+ level was found to be 5.5 mEq/L. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Becomes more positive

 

Explanation

 

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause a shift in the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value, increased cell excitability, and impairments in membrane potential changes.

 

Hyperkalemia can affect the resting membrane potential of cells, including neurons and muscle cells, in the following ways:

 

  1. Increased Resting Membrane Potential: Normally, the resting membrane potential is around -70 millivolts (mV) in neurons. However, in hyperkalemia, the elevated extracellular potassium concentration can lead to an increased positive charge outside the cell. This positive charge tends to depolarize the cell membrane, shifting the resting membrane potential towards a more positive value.
  2. Altered Excitability: The increased resting membrane potential caused by hyperkalemia can make the cell more excitable. It reduces the threshold required for an action potential to be initiated, making the cell more likely to depolarize and generate an action potential even in response to weaker stimuli.
  3. Impaired Membrane Potential Changes: Hyperkalemia can interfere with the ability of the cell membrane to depolarize and repolarize properly during an action potential. It reduces the electrochemical gradient for sodium (Na+) entry during depolarization and decreases the driving force for potassium (K+) exit during repolarization. This can result in slower and less efficient propagation of action potentials.
  4.  Disrupted Ionic Balance: Elevated potassium levels can disrupt the balance of other ions, such as sodium and calcium, which are essential for normal cell function. The altered ionic balance can interfere with the proper functioning of ion channels and other membrane proteins involved in generating and regulating action potentials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No change: Incorrect. Changes in extracellular potassium concentrations directly impact the resting membrane potential.

 

Option B. Becomes more negative: Incorrect. An increase in extracellular potassium concentration results in depolarization (more positive resting membrane potential), not hyperpolarization.

 

Option D. First becomes more positive, then negative: Incorrect. While complex fluctuations can occur under dynamic conditions, primarily, hyperkalemia causes a persistent depolarization (more positive shift) without an initial opposite change.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hyperkalemia, as seen in patients with severe muscle injury, the resting membrane potential becomes more positive due to decreased potassium efflux, leading to increased excitability of nerve and muscle cells. This can affect the normal function of these cells, potentially leading to complications such as muscle weakness or cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limb and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following is the next investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum Potassium

 

Disturbance in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Magnesium: Incorrect for this scenario as disturbances in magnesium typically cause tetany (muscle spasms) when low and generalized weakness when high, but are less directly linked to the type of ascending muscle weakness described.

 

Option C. Serum Sodium: Incorrect because changes in serum sodium levels generally affect neurological function but do not typically cause muscular weakness.

 

Option D. Serum Calcium: Incorrect as calcium imbalances would more likely cause tetany (from hypocalcemia) or symptoms like fatigue, depression, and cardiac arrhythmias (from hypercalcemia), rather than ascending muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The disturbances in serum potassium levels can manifest as muscle weakness, making it a vital test in cases of unexplained, ascending muscle weakness without trauma.

choices.text: Iso-volumetric contraction
Slow filling at end of diastole
End of systole
Start of diastole

questions.text: 'c' wave in JVP is seen in which phase of cardiac cycle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iso-volumetric contraction

 

Explanation

 

'c' waves are produced by bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during the Iso-volumetric contraction of the right ventricle.

 

The isovolumetric contraction phase is characterized by a closed tricuspid valve and a still-closed pulmonary valve, which causes the pressure in the ventricle to rise rapidly without changing its volume.

 

 

Fig: Intra-arterial pressure changes during cardiac cycle. a, c, v= Positive wave x, x1, y= Negative waves

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Slow filling at end of diastole: Incorrect because this phase involves the heart filling with blood, not contracting.

 

Option C. End of systole: Incorrect as this phase corresponds to the onset of ventricular relaxation, not contraction.

 

Option D. Start of diastole: Incorrect because the start of diastole is marked by ventricular relaxation and opening of the atrioventricular valves for ventricular filling, not contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following types of amino acids are present in the trans-membranous part of the membrane receptor? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hydrophobic

 

Integral or transmembrane proteins are the proteins that pass through entire thickness of cell membrane from one side to the other side. These proteins are tightly bound with the cell membrane.

 

The trans membranous part of the membrane receptor consists of hydrophobic amino acids.

 

The central core of the cell membrane is hydrophobic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amphipathic: Incorrect. Amphipathic molecules contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic regions, but the transmembrane segments of proteins are primarily hydrophobic.

 

Option C. Hydrophilic: Incorrect. Hydrophilic amino acids have polar side chains that would not favorably interact with the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect. Hydrophobic amino acids are indeed present in the transmembranous part of the membrane receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmembrane regions of membrane receptors are composed of hydrophobic amino acids, allowing them to stably integrate into the hydrophobic core of the lipid bilayer.

 

Examples of integral protein:

 

  1. Cell adhesion proteins
  2. Cell junction proteins
  3. Some carrier (transport) proteins
  4. Channel proteins
  5. Some hormone receptors
  6. Antigens
  7. Some enzymes.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LH

 

The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

 

Human chorionic gonadotropin is a glycoprotein having a molecular weight of about 39,000 and much the same molecular structure and function as luteinizing hormone secreted by the pituitary gland. Its most important function is to prevent involution of the corpus luteum at the end of the monthly female sexual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FSH: Incorrect. Although FSH is also a glycoprotein hormone, it has a different function and structure compared to hCG.

 

Option C. ACTH: Incorrect. ACTH is a peptide hormone involved in the stress response, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Option D. Oxytocin: Incorrect. Oxytocin is a peptide hormone involved in labor and milk ejection, with a different structure and function compared to hCG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to Luteinizing Hormone (LH). Its primary role is to support the corpus luteum during early pregnancy, preventing its involution.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Facilitated diffusion

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts the process of facilitated diffusion. This type of transport involves the use of carrier proteins embedded in the cell membrane to help molecules that cannot readily diffuse through the lipid bilayer move across the membrane, down their concentration gradient, without the expenditure of cellular energy (ATP).

 

  • Facilitated Diffusion: This process helps molecules move from an area of higher concentration to one of lower concentration via specific carrier proteins. It is a passive transport method since it does not require energy from ATP but relies on the concentration gradient.
  • Carrier Proteins: These proteins undergo a change in shape to transport molecules across the membrane. They are specific to the substances they transport, ensuring selective and regulated transport into and out of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple Diffusion: Involves the movement of molecules directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the assistance of membrane proteins, driven solely by their concentration gradient.

 

Option C. Primary Active Transport: Requires ATP to move substances against their concentration gradient via pumps.

 

Option D. Secondary Active Transport: Also known as co-transport, uses the gradient of one molecule to move another molecule against its gradient, indirectly using energy but not directly using ATP.

 

Educational Objective:
